001package imagingbook.lib.math;
002
003import static imagingbook.lib.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
004
005import java.util.ArrayList;
006import java.util.Arrays;
007import java.util.Collections;
008import java.util.Comparator;
009import java.util.List;
010
011import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.EigenDecomposition;
012import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
013
014/**
015 * Calculates eigenvalues and eigenvectors of square matrices of arbitrary size.
016 * Eigenvalues are sorted by magnitude (in descending order).
017 * A matrix may have complex eigenvalues but only real eigenvalues (and their
018 * associated eigenvectors) are considered.
019 * Uses class {@link EigenDecomposition} of the Apache Commons Math (3) library.
020 * 
021 * @author WB
022 * @version 2021/04/20
023 *
024 */
025public class EigensolverNxN implements RealEigensolver {
026
027        private final EigenDecomposition ed;
028        private final double[] eVals;
029        private final int[] permutation;
030
031        public EigensolverNxN(double[][] M) {
032                if (!Matrix.isSquare(M)) {
033                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("matrix M must be square");
034                }
035                this.ed = new EigenDecomposition(MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(M));
036                this.eVals = new double[M.length];
037                this.permutation = sortEigenvalues(ed.getRealEigenvalues(), ed.getImagEigenvalues());
038                //print();
039        }
040        
041        /**
042         * Returns {@code true} iff all eigenvalues of the associated matrix are real.
043         * @return as described
044         */
045        @Override
046        public boolean isReal() {
047                return !ed.hasComplexEigenvalues();
048        }
049
050        /**
051         * Returns a vector of eigenvalues, sorted by magnitude (in descending order).
052         * {@code Double.Nan} is inserted for complex eigenvalues.
053         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
054         * array and thus results should be used read-only!
055         * @return an array of eigenvalues
056         */
057        @Override
058        public double[] getEigenvalues() {
059                return eVals;
060        }
061
062        /**
063         * Returns the k-th eigenvalue (&lambda;_k, for k = 0,...,N-1).
064         * Eigenvalues are sorted by magnitude (in descending order).
065         * {@code Double.Nan} is returned if the associated eigenvalue
066         * is complex-valued (non-real).
067         * @param k index 
068         * @return the kth eigenvalue
069         */
070        @Override
071        public double getEigenvalue(int k) {
072                return eVals[k];
073        }
074
075        /**
076         * Returns the kth eigenvector.
077         * The ordering of the returned eigenvectors is the same as for the
078         * eigenvalues returned by {@link #getEigenvalues()}.
079         * @param k index
080         * @return the kth eigenvector
081         */
082        @Override
083        public double[] getEigenvector(int k) {
084                return ed.getEigenvector(permutation[k]).toArray();
085        }
086        
087        // -----------------------------------------------------
088        
089        /**
090         * Sorts eigenvalues by magnitude (in descending order, including complex eigenvalues),
091         * inserts sorted values into {@link #eVals} (NaN for complex eigenvalues),
092         * and returns the associated permutation array.
093         * @param re real parts of all eigenvalues
094         * @param im imaginary parts of all eigenvalues
095         * @return the permutation array for sorting by magnitude
096         */
097        private int[] sortEigenvalues(double[] re, double[] im) {
098                final int n = re.length;
099                double[] mag = new double[n];
100                for (int k = 0; k < n; k++) {
101                        mag[k] = Math.sqrt(sqr(re[k]) + sqr(im[k]));
102                }
103                
104                // inspired by https://stackoverflow.com/a/11998394
105                List<Integer> indices = new ArrayList<>(mag.length);
106                for (int i = 0; i < mag.length; i++) {
107                        indices.add(i);
108                }
109                
110                Comparator<Integer> comparator = new Comparator<Integer>() {
111                        @Override
112                        public int compare(Integer a, Integer b) {
113                                return Double.compare(mag[b], mag[a]);
114                        }
115                };
116
117                Collections.sort(indices, comparator);
118                int[] perm = indices.stream().mapToInt(Integer::intValue).toArray();
119                
120                // Rearrange 'eVals' and replace complex eigenvalues by NaN:
121                for (int k = 0; k < n; k++) {
122                        int j = perm[k];
123                        eVals[k] = (Arithmetic.isZero(im[j])) ? re[j] : Double.NaN;
124                }
125                return perm;
126        }
127        
128
129        @SuppressWarnings("unused")
130        private void print() {
131                System.out.println("hasComplexEigenvalues = " + ed.hasComplexEigenvalues());
132                double[] evalsR = ed.getRealEigenvalues();
133                double[] evalsI = ed.getImagEigenvalues();
134                System.out.format("evalsR = %s\n", Arrays.toString(evalsR));
135                System.out.format("evalsI = %s\n", Arrays.toString(evalsI));
136                
137                for (int k = 0; k < evalsR.length; k++) {
138                        double[] evecR = ed.getEigenvector(k).toArray();
139                        System.out.format("%d: eval=%f | evec=%s\n", k, getEigenvalue(k), Arrays.toString(getEigenvector(k)));
140                }
141        }
142
143        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
144

170//                              System.out.format("   M*x = %s\n", Arrays.toString(Matrix.multiply(M, x)));

173//              }
174//      }
175}
